summary: A 2006 Palm Beach Post article detailing the early stages of the Jeffrey Epstein investigation, reporting that his lawyer Alan Dershowitz tried to discredit teenage accusers, that a plea deal was allegedly offered and accepted but later denied, and that private investigators harassed victims' families. The article reveals police frustration with the state attorney's handling and the referral of the case to the FBI.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.role: Defense Attorney for Jeffrey Epstein, Harvard law professor
persons.context: Met with the State Attorney's Office to provide damaging information about the teenage girls accusing Epstein; was allegedly offered a plea deal for Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Indicted by a grand jury on one count of felony solicitation of prostitution; accused by teenage girls of sexually charged massages.

persons.name: Michael Reiter
persons.role: Police Chief, Palm Beach Police Department
persons.context: Was angry about the handling of the case, wrote a memo suggesting the State Attorney disqualify himself, and later referred the matter to the FBI.

persons.name: Barry Krischer
persons.context: The prosecutor whose office handled the case and presented it to a grand jury; was the subject of a critical memo from Police Chief Reiter.

persons.name: Joseph Recarey
persons.context: Prepared the police report detailing the investigation, including the alleged plea deal and witness intimidation.

persons.name: Lanna Belohlavek
persons.context: Allegedly offered a plea deal to Epstein's attorneys in April.

persons.name: Guy Fronstin
persons.context: Allegedly accepted a plea deal for Epstein in April but was subsequently fired; declined to comment.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: Hired after Fronstin was fired; denies any plea deal was agreed to and comments on Epstein's polygraph test.

persons.name: Judy Orihuela
persons.context: Confirmed the FBI was reviewing the referral from Police Chief Reiter.

persons.name: Gerald Lefcourt
persons.role: Defense Attorney for Jeffrey Epstein (New York)
persons.context: Prominent New York lawyer who criticized Police Chief Reiter, saying the indictment resulted from the chief's 'craziness'.

persons.name: Mike Edmondson
persons.context: Explained the unusual process of presenting the case to a grand jury and that the office did not recommend a specific charge.

persons.name: Richard Tendler
persons.context: Commented that the grand jury proceeding was a way for the prosecutor to avoid responsibility, suggesting issues with the underage witnesses.

persons.name: Robert Gershman
persons.context: Speculated that the accusers must have been 'incredible or untrustworthy' for the case to go to a grand jury.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: Was involved in Epstein's defense at one point; known for defending William Kennedy Smith.

persons.name: Michelle Suskauer
persons.context: Commented on the public perception that powerful defendants like Epstein are treated differently.

persons.name: Former President Clinton
persons.context: Mentioned as one of Epstein's high-profile friends, raising questions about preferential treatment.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned as one of Epstein's high-profile friends, raising questions about preferential treatment.

connections.description: Dershowitz is identified as a defense attorney for Epstein, meeting with prosecutors on his behalf.
Fronstin was an attorney for Epstein who allegedly accepted a plea deal on his behalf before being fired.
Goldberger was hired as Epstein's defense attorney after Fronstin was fired and publicly denies any plea deal.
Lefcourt is identified as Epstein's prominent New York lawyer who publicly defended him.
Mentioned as friends, part of the narrative about Epstein's powerful connections.
Mentioned as friends, part of the narrative about Epstein's powerful connections.
Reiter wrote a memo suggesting Krischer disqualify himself from the Epstein case due to dissatisfaction with the handling.
Recarey's police report documents Belohlavek's alleged offer of a plea deal to Epstein's attorneys.

events.title: Grand Jury Indictment of Epstein
events.description: A Palm Beach County grand jury indicted Jeffrey Epstein on a single count of felony solicitation of prostitution, following accusations by teenage girls.

events.title: Alleged Plea Deal Offer
events.description: Prosecutor Lanna Belohlavek allegedly offered a plea deal to Epstein's attorneys (Dershowitz and Fronstin). The deal would have had Epstein plead guilty to aggravated assault, receive probation, and have no criminal record.

events.title: Police Chief's Memo to State Attorney
events.description: Police Chief Michael Reiter wrote a memo to State Attorney Barry Krischer suggesting he disqualify himself from the Epstein case, expressing anger over its handling.

events.title: Case Referred to FBI
events.description: After Epstein's indictment was unsealed, Police Chief Reiter referred the matter to the FBI for review.

events.title: Grand Jury Presentation Postponed
events.description: The initial presentation of the case to a grand jury was postponed after Alan Dershowitz provided information from Myspace.com about the alleged victims' comments on alcohol and marijuana use.

keyFacts: Epstein's defense team, led by Alan Dershowitz, actively worked to discredit the teenage accusers by providing information from Myspace.com about their alcohol and marijuana use to prosecutors.

A plea deal was allegedly offered and accepted by Epstein's then-attorney Guy Fronstin in April 2006, which would have resulted in no criminal record for Epstein, but his subsequent attorney Jack Goldberger denies any deal was agreed to.
Private investigators working for Epstein's side aggressively followed and photographed the homes of victims' families, with vehicles traced to investigators in West Palm Beach and Jupiter.

Police believed there was probable cause for more serious charges (unlawful sex acts with a minor, lewd and lascivious molestation), but the grand jury only indicted on one count of felony solicitation of prostitution.
The case was referred to the FBI by Police Chief Michael Reiter due to dissatisfaction with the local state attorney's handling, indicating early federal interest.
